It's basically a paint by numbers puzzle game where someone forgot to paint the numbers.Aside from the utter lack of anything resembling artwork in the game, the puzzles themselves are pretty boring and pointless.  The block elements in the game don't really lend themselves to interesting or intuitive puzzles, and your interactions with the various blocks are limited to one of two actions.Also, in the director's cut, there's some sort of thin, pointless story thrown on top.  It's totally disconnected from the game however, so instead of being mildly annoying like most pointless stories in video games, in QUBE it's actively distracting since you'll be scratching your head trying to figure out what the story has to do with the boring white room you're currently in.

												Decent little game.  I enjoyed both the puzzles and the story.  The voice acting and visual style both impressed me.  Simple but polished.  Not quite on the level of Portal, but if you've played Portal and want more, this will likely suit your taste.The controls are a weak point.  I'm going to talk a little about that, and I don't want you to think this means I didn't like the game, because I did.In some parts, you have to aim very carefully (there's no auto-targetting help), fairly quickly, and the targetting reticle is often nearly invisible.  The shot cooldown is applied unnecessarily to all situations, including color-change targets which often need to be shot twice (shoot it once, click to shoot again, turn elsewhere, notice that your second shot didn't go through, turn back, find the first target...), so these parts of the game feel can very clunky and frustrating.  Jumping is never very good in a first-person game, and it's an annoyance here as well.  In particular, when you're standing on narrow platforms, and you have to walk toward where you're jumping, it does that FPS thing where walking into the wall at even a slight angle makes you slide along it.  Because of this, and because you can't see your feet, it's easy to accidentally walk off a platform, and also to miss your jump at a precipice.  At times you need to aim nearly straight up or straight down, and due to an overly simple polar coordinate control model the mouse control is very awkward at this; it makes sense, but doesn't feel natural or work well.The main story mode is not, by any means, an action game, so there's no real enjoyment in learning to skillfully and precisely control it.  It's a puzzle game, and fiddly controls just cause annoying blunders and waste your time.  The controls are better suited to the timed-run bonus levels, but in today's market full of cheap, good games, I don't think the bonus content is a good use of anyone's time.These things could be fixed with, I think, little effort, which makes them all the more grating in a project where so much was done with obvious attention to detail.

ThoughtsShort (3-4 hours) but enjoyable experience despite the very poor story line (or lack of story at all really).  The game revolves around a guy in a cube spaceship who must solve challenges using different coloured cubes to progress through the levels to try and escape the spaceship.  The story is extremely disappointing and really doesnt add anything to the game in my opinion.  I was left confused by it at the end and because its so random i felt no urge to even look up what it was about.  It had zero lasting effect on me in this sense.The puzzle elements of the game however are really well done and although not massively challenging they are also not frustrating either.  The game has some hidden puzzles which are a little harder but again nothing to hard.  The game revolves around using some special gloves that allow you to manipulate cubes to progress to the next area/level. Each cube is a different colour and they all act differently, you need to use a combination of the cubes to progress through the level with some timing needed also.The directors cut includes speed runs which i personally am not interested in but it might appeal to others.Overall i enjoyed the game from a puzzle aspect and if you are a fan of puzzle games i would recommend it especially when its on sale for less than £2.  However dont expect any gripping story line from this title.Steam Controller SupportThe game doesnt have any native controller support so the input for the steam controller needs to be configured using keyboard and mouse inputs.  I initially grabbed the top used config and adjusted the mouse input sensitivity to my liking.  The game works fine with this input method and using the triggers for left and right click to manipulate the cubes worked really well.Menu navigation was a little different but i blame the game rather than the controller for this as it was created for mouse navigation.Steam Link SupportNo major issues using this game with the steam link, 1080p @ 60fps without problems.  Menu text was a little small.

												This game is pretty straight-forward, which is a good thing.  The game was overall refreshing, and it played well (meaning, no performance issues or serious glitches).  Most of the puzzles were modestly challenging, though few were exceptionally difficult.  But unlike games such as Portal, the puzzles can only be so complicated before they're totally overwhelming.  But, the developers seemed to do a good job at avoiding any overwhelming puzzles (though, I hadn't found all of the hidden ones yet).I would like to point out that there were a couple puzzles that were a bit clumsy to solve, where I "solved" them by exploiting inconsistencies in the physics engine.  Though the level design may be clever, the physics engine can sometimes make the puzzles seem a lot less elegant.My biggest gripe with the game is the overall effort put into it, particularly toward the end.  The ending was very sudden.  It felt incomplete, rushed, and as though the developers lost interest.  I liked the psychological dichotomy in the story, but it felt like the entire concept of that was completely thrown away at the very end.  It would have been nice to have at least been given a choice to how the game ends.TL;DR:Decent game to get on sale and play during a weekend.  But the physics need refinement, it's visually boring, and the story is anticlimactic.

												Pros:Technically robust.Aesthetically pleasing visuals.Cons:Frustrating, slow and unsatisfying game mechanics and puzzles.Pacing problems.Ham-fisted story.Extremely annoying time buffers in the levels to accomodate audio narrative.My biggest personal gripe with the design of this game are all the forced waiting periods between puzzles, such as slow-opening doors, slow-moving elevators or poitlessly long corridors, which don't adapt to the player's pacing at all and will force you to wait idly in silence if you stopped to look or explore while the audio-only narrative played out.The audio narrative should've been playing during the puzzles, not in between!Or at least speed up the arbitrary waiting points if the audio already stopped playing!And to add insult to injury, the achievements indicate that there are hidden secrets in some stages, so exploration is both incentivized (with secrets) and punished (with pointless waiting if you lingered a bit between puzzles).I can tolerate a pointless story, but not when it gets in the way of the game proper.As for the core of game, I'd describe it as "Portal-esque, but oddly unsatisfying."Most of the game is spent trying to guide balls or cubes through obstacle courses by remotely triggering fixed gadgets in the level, which turns out to be a boring, repetitive and frustrating task.I imagine some people will love what this game has to give, but I was not one of them, and I generally can't recommend it.
